paragraphs.context: The Panthers and Broncos met in Super Bowl 50 after earning the top seeds in their conferences for the third consecutive season. The Panthers joined a select group of ten teams with just one regular season loss and were one of six teams to finish with a 15-1 record. The Broncos, on the other hand, were one of four teams to make eight Super Bowl appearances. This was the Broncos' second Super Bowl appearance in three years, following their last appearance in XLVIII, while the Panthers made their second ever appearance, with their first being in XXXVIII. Notably, both teams were led by John Fox in their most recent Super Bowl appearance before Super Bowl 50.

paragraphs.context: Despite releasing DeAngelo Williams and losing Kelvin Benjamin to a torn ACL in the preseason, the Carolina Panthers had their best regular season in franchise history, becoming the seventh team to win at least 15 regular season games since the league expanded to a 16-game schedule in 1978. Carolina began the season 14-0, setting franchise records for the best start and the longest winning streak in a single season. They also had the best start to a season by an NFC team in NFL history, surpassing the 13-0 record shared by the 2009 New Orleans Saints and the 2011 Green Bay Packers. With their NFC-leading 15-1 regular season record, the Panthers secured home-field advantage throughout the NFC playoffs for the first time in franchise history. The team had ten Pro Bowl selections (the most in franchise history) and eight All-Pro selections.

paragraphs.context: The Panthers offense, which scored 500 points to lead the NFL, had a lot of talent with six Pro Bowl selections. Quarterback Cam Newton had a standout season, throwing for 3,837 yards and rushing for 636. He had 45 total touchdowns (35 passing, 10 rushing), only 10 interceptions, and a career-best quarterback rating of 99.4. Newton's top targets were tight end Greg Olsen (77 catches, 1,104 yards, seven touchdowns) and Ted Ginn, Jr. (44 catches, 739 yards, 10 touchdowns). Other key receivers were Jerricho Cotchery (39 catches), rookie Devin Funchess (31 catches, five touchdowns), and Corey Brown (31 catches). Running back Jonathan Stewart led the team with 989 rushing yards and six touchdowns.

paragraphs.context: After a disappointing playoff loss, the Denver Broncos made changes at head coach, parting ways with John Fox who had led the team to four division championships. Gary Kubiak was brought in as the new head coach and implemented a run-focused offense to complement quarterback Peyton Manning's passing ability. However, Manning struggled with a plantar fasciitis injury in his heel and his age, turning 39 that offseason. Despite a strong start to the season, Manning led the league in interceptions and suffered a partial tear of the plantar fasciitis in his left foot. Backup quarterback Brock Osweiler took over until he was injured, leading to Manning's return and a key win over the San Diego Chargers to secure the AFC's top seed for the playoffs. The Broncos' defense, under Wade Phillips, was top-ranked in various categories and helped carry the team to a 12-4 record and home-field advantage in the playoffs.

paragraphs.context: The field at Levi's Stadium had to be re-sodded multiple times during its inaugural season, causing concerns about its quality for hosting a Super Bowl. To prepare for the Super Bowl, a new playing surface was installed; a hybrid Bermuda 419 turf. NFL and Atlanta Braves field director Ed Mangan deemed the field in "great shape" for gameday. paragraphs.context: On June 4, 2014, the NFL made an announcement that they would be taking a break from using Roman numerals to brand the Super Bowl games, starting with Super Bowl 50 instead of calling it Super Bowl L using Arabic numerals. They will go back to using Roman numerals for Super Bowl LI. Jaime Weston, who is the league's vice president of brand and creative, cited challenges in designing a logo with the letter "L" using the logo template introduced at Super Bowl XLV as the main reason for the change. The logo for Super Bowl LI also stands out as it features large gold numerals behind the Vince Lombardi Trophy, departing from the standard logo design.

paragraphs.context: In Super Bowl 50, the Denver Broncos set records for the lowest total yards (194) and first downs (11) ever by a winning team. The previous record was held by the Baltimore Ravens who had 244 yards in Super Bowl XXXV. Only seven other teams had gained less than 200 yards in a Super Bowl and all of them had lost. Denver's seven sacks tied a record set by the Chicago Bears in Super Bowl XX. Jordan Norwood set a new record with a 61-yard punt return, surpassing John Taylor's record of 45 yards in Super Bowl XXIII. Manning and Newton had passer ratings of 56.6 and 55.4, resulting in a record low total passer rating of 112 for a Super Bowl. At age 39, Manning became the oldest quarterback to win a Super Bowl and the first to win with two different teams.

paragraphs.context: The Saxon Garden, a former royal garden covering 15.5 hectares, is home to over 100 tree species and beautiful avenues. At the eastern end, the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier can be found. Krasiński Palace Garden, renovated in the 19th century, showcases old trees like maidenhair, black walnut, Turkish hazel, and Caucasian wingnut. The park also features benches, flower beds, a pond, and a playground, making it a popular spot for locals. Łazienki Park, spanning 76 hectares, boasts unique architecture, sculptures, and a variety of trees and shrubs, as well as peacocks and pheasants roaming freely. Wilanów Palace Park, dating back to the 17th century, includes a French-style area and a garden with a terrace facing a pond. The park around Królikarnia Palace is situated on a Vistula escarpment and features lanes running through ravines on both sides of the palace.

paragraphs.context: Around 15 kilometres (9 miles) from Warsaw, the environment of the Vistula river changes significantly, showcasing a well-preserved ecosystem that is home to animals such as the otter, beaver, and hundreds of bird species. In Warsaw, there are 13 natural reserves, including Bielany Forest, Kabaty Woods, and Czerniaków Lake. The city also boasts several lakes, like the oxbow lakes and those found in parks like Łazienki and Wilanów. Most lakes in Warsaw parks are emptied before winter to clean them of plants and sediments.

paragraphs.context: Warsaw, historically known for its diverse population, had a significant Jewish minority making up around 34% of the city according to the Russian census of 1897. Before World War II, the Jewish population in Warsaw was over 350,000, accounting for about 30% of the total population. In 1933, out of 1,178,914 residents, 833,500 spoke Polish as their mother tongue. Today, the city has experienced changes in demographics with less ethnic diversity compared to its past. The current population growth is mainly due to internal migration and urbanization.

paragraphs.context: Kraków was the Polish capital city in 1313 when Warsaw was first mentioned in history. This city survived many wars, conflicts, and invasions and eventually became the capital of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland in 1596 when King Sigismund III Vasa moved his court there from Kraków. Since then, it has withstood various challenges and foreign occupations, including incorporation into the Kingdom of Prussia in 1795 and annexation by the Russian Empire in 1815. Despite these hardships, Warsaw has always managed to rise again, earning the nickname of the "Phoenix City." This resilience was evident in the city's recovery after suffering extensive damage during World War II, with 85% of its buildings destroyed. In recognition of its bravery during the Siege of Warsaw in 1939, the city was awarded Poland's highest military honor, the Virtuti Militari, on 9 November 1940.

paragraphs.context: Following the start of the Second World War with the German Invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939, Warsaw defended itself until September 27. Central Poland, including Warsaw, was placed under the control of the General Government, which was a German Nazi colonial administration. Closing down all higher education institutions, several hundred thousand Jews, around 30% of the city's population, were forced into the Warsaw Ghetto. The city became a hub of resistance against German Nazi rule in occupied Europe. On 19 April 1943, the German Nazis ordered the Ghetto's annihilation as part of Hitler's "Final Solution", leading to the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising by Jewish fighters. Despite being outnumbered and outgunned, the Ghetto held out for nearly a month. Following the end of the fighting, most survivors were tragically massacred, with only a few managing to escape or find hiding spots.

paragraphs.context: In the late 17th century, noble palaces and churches in Warsaw saw increased building activity. Notable examples from this period include Krasiński Palace (built 1677–1683), Wilanów Palace (constructed 1677–1696), and St. Kazimierz Church (completed 1688–1692). The rococo style was showcased in buildings like Czapski Palace (built 1712–1721), Palace of the Four Winds (from the 1730s), and Visitationist Church (façade built 1728–1761). Neoclassical architecture in Warsaw, influenced by Roman design, featured simple geometrical forms. Key neoclassical structures included the rebuilt Palace on the Water (1775–1795), Królikarnia (1782–1786), Carmelite Church (façade built 1761–1783), and Evangelical Holy Trinity Church (constructed 1777–1782). The economic growth in early Congress Poland spurred a rapid architectural expansion, with examples like the Great Theater (built 1825–1833) and Bank Square buildings (constructed 1825–1828) showcasing a Neoclassical revival.

paragraphs.context: In 1900, Tesla was granted patents for transmitting electrical energy and an electrical transmitter. When Guglielmo Marconi achieved the first transatlantic radio transmission in 1901, Tesla joked that it was done with 17 Tesla patents, although there is little evidence to support this. This marked the start of legal battles over radio patents, with Tesla's patents initially upheld in 1903, but later reversed in favor of Marconi in 1904. In 1943, the Supreme Court of the United States decision restored Tesla, Oliver Lodge, and John Stone's prior patents. The court clarified that while Marconi was credited with the first radio transmission, his claim to certain patents was in question, preventing him from claiming infringement on those same patents. It has been suggested that the high court was attempting to nullify a World War I claim by the Marconi Company against the U.S. government by restoring Tesla's prior patent.

paragraphs.context: During his time at his lab, Tesla noticed unusual signals from his receiver that he believed could possibly be messages from another planet. He mentioned these in a letter to reporter Julian Hawthorne at the Philadelphia North American on 8 December 1899 and in another letter to the Red Cross Society in December 1900 where he talked about possible discoveries in the upcoming century, referring to messages "from another world" that read "1... 2... 3...". Reporters sensationalized the story, assuming Tesla was picking up signals from Mars. In a 9 February 1901 article for Collier's Weekly titled "Talking With Planets", Tesla discussed the signals further, mentioning that he was not initially aware they were "intelligently controlled signals" and suggesting they could be from Mars, Venus, or other planets. paragraphs.context: In computational complexity theory, the aim is to explore the limits of what computers are capable of by analyzing mathematical models of computation. paragraphs.context: The closely connected fields within theoretical computer science include analysis of algorithms and computability theory. Computational complexity theory aims to classify problems as solvable or unsolvable with limited resources, setting it apart from computability theory which explores what types of problems can be algorithmically solved in theory.

paragraphs.context: A Turing machine is a theoretical model of computation that works by manipulating symbols on a tape. While not meant for practical use, a Turing machine is a thought experiment representing various computing machines. If a problem can be solved by an algorithm, there is a Turing machine that can also solve it, according to the Church-Turing thesis. It is known that anything computable on other models of computation can also be computed on a Turing machine. Due to their mathematical simplicity and theoretical power, Turing machines are widely used in complexity theory.

paragraphs.context: The basic form of a Turing machine is the deterministic one, which follows a fixed set of rules to decide its next moves. Adding random bits to a deterministic Turing machine results in a probabilistic Turing machine, which can make probabilistic decisions to solve problems more efficiently through randomized algorithms. For a more complex approach, a non-deterministic Turing machine expands on the deterministic one by introducing non-determinism, where multiple future actions are possible from a given state. This model, while not physically realizable, creates interesting complexity classes in theoretical computer science. Examples of non-deterministic algorithms can be found for further understanding.

paragraphs.context: In order to define how a problem can be solved within a specific amount of time and space, a computational model such as the deterministic Turing machine is utilized. The time taken by a deterministic Turing machine M when given input x is determined by the total number of state transitions, or steps, it goes through before producing the answer ("yes" or "no"). A Turing machine M is considered to run within time f(n) if the time it takes on an input of length n is at most f(n). A decision problem A can be resolved within time f(n) if there exists a Turing machine that can solve it within that time frame. Complexity theory aims to classify problems based on their level of difficulty by defining sets of problems using certain criteria. For example, the collection of problems that can be solved within time f(n) on a deterministic Turing machine is denoted by DTIME(f(n)).

paragraphs.context: An instance where the worst case scenario arises is in the context of the deterministic sorting algorithm quicksort. This algorithm is designed to efficiently sort a list of integers. In the worst-case scenario, which is when the input list is already sorted or sorted in reverse order, quicksort takes O(n2) time to complete. If we assume that all potential permutations of the input are equally probable, the average time taken for sorting is O(n log n). The best case scenario occurs when the pivoting consistently splits the list in half, also requiring O(n log n) time.

Establishing upper and lower bounds is crucial in assessing the time complexity of algorithms. When proving an upper bound, one must demonstrate that there exists an algorithm with a running time no greater than T(n). On the other hand, proving lower bounds is more challenging as it involves making a statement about all potential algorithms that could solve the problem, both those currently known and any future discoveries. Demonstrating a lower bound for a problem requires showing that no algorithm can have a time complexity below T(n).

paragraphs.context: Complexity classes are often defined using reductions, which involve transforming a problem into another to show its level of difficulty relative to another problem. For example, if a problem X can be solved using an algorithm for Y, then X reduces to Y. There are various methods of reductions, like Cook reductions, Karp reductions, and Levin reductions, as well as different bounds on the complexity of reductions, such as polynomial-time or log-space reductions.

paragraphs.context: The most frequently utilized reduction is one that can be completed in polynomial time. This indicates that the process of reduction is completed within a polynomial amount of time. For instance, the task of finding the square of an integer can be simplified to the task of multiplying two integers. This implies that an algorithm designed for multiplying two integers can be utilized to find the square of an integer. In fact, this can be achieved by providing the same input to both inputs of the multiplication algorithm. Therefore, it can be observed that finding the square of an integer is not more challenging than multiplication, as squaring can be reduced to multiplication.

paragraphs.context: This concept discusses the difficulty of problems within a certain complexity class. A problem X is considered hard for a group of problems C if every problem in C can be transformed into X. Therefore, no problem in C is considered harder than X, as solving X enables us to solve any problem in C. The difficulty of problems is influenced by the type of reduction implemented. For complexity classes beyond P, reductions that run in polynomial time are typically utilized. Specifically, the collection of problems that present challenges for NP is categorized as NP-hard problems.

paragraphs.context: If a problem X is in class C and poses a challenge for C, then X is considered complete for C, making it the toughest problem in C. The class of NP-complete problems consists of the most challenging problems in NP, as they are least likely to have a polynomial-time solution. As the problem P = NP remains unsolved, reducing a known NP-complete problem, Π2, to another problem, Π1, would imply that there is no polynomial-time solution known for Π1. This is because a polynomial-time solution for Π1 would also solve Π2 in polynomial time. Discovering an NP-complete problem that can be solved in polynomial time would indicate that P = NP.

paragraphs.context: The unsolved computational problem known as the graph isomorphism problem involves determining if two finite graphs are isomorphic. There is ongoing debate within complexity theory regarding whether this problem is in P, NP-complete, or NP-intermediate. If graph isomorphism is NP-complete, then the polynomial time hierarchy would collapse to its second level. However, many believe that the polynomial hierarchy does not collapse to any finite level, indicating that graph isomorphism is not NP-complete. Laszlo Babai and Eugene Luks developed the best algorithm for this problem, with a run time of 2O(√(n log(n))) for graphs with n vertices.

paragraphs.context: In complexity theory, problems that cannot be solved in polynomial time are considered intractable for inputs larger than the smallest. The Cobham–Edmonds thesis suggests that only problems solvable in polynomial time are feasible on a computational device. EXPTIME-hard problems are examples of those deemed intractable. If NP does not equal P, then NP-complete problems are also intractable. Exponential-time algorithms may not be practical due to the immense amount of time required for execution. For instance, a program with 2n operations may run for billions of years before completion. Even with faster technology, such algorithms are only useful for very small instances. Polynomial time algorithms are not always efficient either, especially those with running times like n15.

paragraphs.context: The practical meaning of intractability is debatable. Just because a problem is not in P doesn't mean that all large cases of the problem are difficult. For instance, the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem may not be in P, but algorithms have been developed to solve it efficiently in most cases. Similarly, the NP-complete knapsack problem can be solved in less than quadratic time for a wide range of sizes, and large instances of the NP-complete Boolean satisfiability problem can be handled by SAT solvers.

Luther believed in the Real Presence of the body and blood of Christ in the consecrated bread and wine, which he termed the sacramental union. However, his opponents saw God as only symbolically or spiritually present. The debate between Luther and Zwingli, for instance, sometimes turned confrontational. Luther emphasized the omnipresence of Jesus' human nature, while Zwingli denied Jesus' ability to be in multiple places simultaneously. paragraphs.context: From December 1539, Luther was involved in the scandal of Philip I, Landgrave of Hesse, wanting to marry one of his wife's ladies-in-waiting. Luther, along with Melanchthon and Bucer, were consulted by Philip, who referred to the polygamy of the patriarchs as a precedent. The theologians hesitated to give a definitive ruling, urging the landgrave to marry in secret if he was set on it. On 4 March 1540, Philip married Margarethe von der Saale as his second wife, witnessed by Melanchthon and Bucer. However, the secret didn't hold, and Philip threatened to expose Luther's involvement. To cover up the scandal, Luther advised Philip to deny the marriage, which led to a public controversy. paragraphs.context: Throughout his career, Luther expressed his views on the Jews, but only a few of his works directly addressed them. Despite rarely encountering Jews in his lifetime, Luther's beliefs were influenced by a theological and cultural tradition that viewed Jews as responsible for the murder of Christ, a sentiment that was reinforced by his local community's expulsion of Jews nearly a century prior. He viewed Jews as blasphemers and liars for denying the divinity of Jesus, which Christians believed in. However, Luther believed that all individuals who opposed God were equally at fault. In 1516, Luther criticized those who insulted Jews, reminding them of their own imperfections in God's eyes. He initially advocated for kindness towards Jews in his 1523 work, That Jesus Christ was Born a Jew, with the aim of converting them to Christianity. When his efforts to convert them proved futile, Luther's sentiments towards Jews took a turn for the worse. Christian author Eric Metaxas suggested in his 2010 book that Luther's attitude towards Jews deteriorated as his health declined.

A first edition of Luther's On the Jews and their Lies was given to Julius Streicher by the city of Nuremberg in 1937, with Der Stürmer calling it the most anti-Semitic tract ever published.

paragraphs.context: On 17 December 1941, a group of Protestant church leaders supported the idea of Jews wearing the yellow badge, citing Luther's views on Jews. Bishop Martin Sasse, considered the greatest antisemite of his time, published a collection of Luther's writings after Kristallnacht. Diarmaid MacCulloch, a history professor, argued that Luther's writings served as a model for anti-Semitic actions. Sasse praised the burning of synagogues, linking it to Luther's birthday, and urged people to listen to the words of "the greatest antisemite of his time" regarding Jews.

paragraphs.context: Some scholars argue that Luther's influence was limited and the Nazis' use of his work was opportunistic. Biographer Martin Brecht emphasizes that Luther's beliefs were entirely religious and in no respect racial, but his misguided agitation inadvertently contributed to the modern hatred of the Jews. Johannes Wallmann and Uwe Siemon-Netto also believe there was no continuity between Luther's teachings and Nazi ideology, as the Nazis were already anti-Semites. Overall, focusing solely on Luther as a precursor to Nazi antisemitism overlooks other historical factors and the entirely religious origins of Luther's views.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1680s, Huguenot refugees fleeing persecution found safety in Lutheran and Reformed states across Germany and Scandinavia. They were given special rights and places of worship thanks to the Edict of Potsdam, including the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul in Angermünde. To show gratitude, the Huguenots contributed two new regiments to Frederick William's army, specifically the Altpreußische Infantry Regiments No. 13 and 15. Other Huguenot refugees found homes in various German territories and cities, such as Baden, Hesse-Kassel, and Hamburg. Additionally, 300 refugees were offered sanctuary at the court of George William, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg in Celle.

paragraphs.context: The atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712, was the first truly successful engine capable of producing power and transferring it to a machine. By creating a vacuum through steam condensation under a piston within a cylinder, the engine was able to drain mine workings and supply water for waterwheels at factories located away from a suitable water source. paragraphs.context: The working fluid is a key factor in determining the efficiency of a Rankine cycle. As the pressure of the working fluid does not reach supercritical levels, the temperature range for the cycle is limited. In steam turbines, the turbine entry temperature is usually set at 565 °C, which is the creep limit of stainless steel, while the condenser temperatures remain around 30 °C. This temperature limitation results in a theoretical Carnot efficiency of approximately 63%, compared to the actual efficiency of 42% in modern coal-fired power stations. The relatively low turbine entry temperature, in comparison to gas turbines, is why the Rankine cycle is commonly used as a bottoming cycle in combined-cycle gas turbine power stations.

paragraphs.context: A steam turbine is made up of rotating discs called rotors on a drive shaft, paired with static discs known as stators on the turbine casing. The rotors have blades on the outer edge that are turned by steam, while the stators have fixed blades that redirect the steam flow. To maximize work output, the stages of the turbine are designed to efficiently extract energy from steam at specific velocities and pressures, resulting in high- and low-pressure stages.  Turbines need to spin at high speeds to be effective, so they are often connected to reduction gearing for lower speed applications, such as propelling a ship. In power stations, turbines are directly linked to generators at speeds like 3600 RPM in the USA, 3000 RPM in Europe, and can run at half-speed in nuclear applications. paragraphs.context: In this dioxygen, the two oxygen atoms are chemically bonded to each other through a covalent double bond, which is formed by filling molecular orbitals created from the atomic orbitals of each individual oxygen atom. The filling of these molecular orbitals gives a bond order of two. Specifically, the double bond is a result of sequential filling of orbitals from low to high energy, known as Aufbau, and involves the cancellation of contributions from the 2s electrons. This process includes filling of low σ and σ* orbitals, σ overlap of the two atomic 2p orbitals along the O-O axis, π overlap of two pairs of atomic 2p orbitals perpendicular to the O-O axis, and the cancellation of contributions from the remaining two of the six 2p electrons after partially filling the lowest π and π* orbitals.

paragraphs.context: The combination of σ and π overlaps leads to the double bond character and reactivity of dioxygen, resulting in a triplet electronic ground state. Dioxygen with its unpaired electrons is in a spin triplet state, with two unpaired electrons occupying equal energy orbitals. This configuration of unpaired electrons is known as a spin triplet state. The ground state of the O2 molecule is commonly referred to as triplet oxygen. The highest energy orbitals in triplet oxygen are antibonding, weakening the bond order from three to two when filled. Due to its unpaired electrons, triplet oxygen reacts slowly with organic molecules, which have paired electron spins, thus preventing spontaneous combustion.

paragraphs.context: Oxygen gas can be harmful when inhaled at elevated partial pressures, causing health issues such as convulsions. Oxygen toxicity usually occurs when the partial pressures exceed 50 kilopascals, which is equivalent to a composition of about 50% oxygen at standard pressure or 2.5 times the normal sea-level O2 partial pressure of about 21 kPa. This is mostly a concern for patients on mechanical ventilators, as oxygen masks used in medical settings typically contain only 30%–50% oxygen (around 30 kPa at standard pressure). However, the percentage can vary widely depending on the type of mask.

paragraphs.context: In October 1973, the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries (OAPEC) initiated the 1973 oil crisis by placing an embargo on oil. By the end of the embargo in March 1974, the global price of oil had surged from $3 per barrel to almost $12, with even higher prices in the US. This oil shock had significant impacts on both global politics and the global economy, marking it as the "first oil shock". It was followed by the 1979 oil crisis, known as the "second oil shock".

paragraphs.context: On August 15, 1971, the United States made the decision to withdraw from the Bretton Woods Accord, resulting in the abandonment of the Gold Exchange Standard. This led to the dollar being allowed to "float" in value according to market demand, causing other currencies to do the same. Following this, industrialized nations increased their reserves significantly in preparation for potential unpredictable fluctuations in currency values. As a result, the dollar and other currencies depreciated. Since oil was priced in dollars, this led to a decrease in real income for oil producers. In September 1971, OPEC announced that oil would now be priced in terms of a fixed amount of gold.

paragraphs.context: Until the oil shock in 1973-1974, the dollar price of oil had been increasing by less than two percent per year from 1947 to 1967. However, after 1971, OPEC was slow to adjust prices to account for this depreciation, leading to their real incomes falling behind. The substantial price hikes in 1973-1974 brought their prices and incomes back to levels seen during the Bretton Woods era in terms of commodities like gold.

Only two, A and B, were finished by October 1965. The LOC also had an Operations and Checkout Building (OCB) where Gemini and Apollo spacecraft were prepared for launch. Around this time, Joseph Shea, the newly hired deputy director at the Manned Spacecraft Center, became a strong supporter of the LOR mode. paragraphs.context: The Saturn IB, an enhancement of the Saturn I, featured the S-IB first stage with 1,600,000 pounds-force (7,120 kN) of thrust. The second stage, the S-IVB-200, utilized a single J-2 engine burning liquid hydrogen fuel and LOX to generate 200,000 lbf (890 kN) of thrust. The third stage of the Saturn V was a restartable version of the S-IVB. Capable of launching over 40,000 pounds (18,100 kg) into low Earth orbit, the Saturn IB could handle a partially fueled CSM or the LM. Launch vehicles and flights of the Saturn IB were identified with an AS-200 series number, with "AS" representing "Apollo Saturn" and the "2" indicating the second Saturn rocket variant.

paragraphs.context: The three-stage Saturn V, measuring 33 feet in diameter, was created to transport a fully fueled CSM and LM to the Moon. Standing at a height of 363 feet, it had a 96,800-pound lunar payload which later increased to 103,600 pounds. The S-IC first stage used RP-1/LOX and had a rated thrust of 7,500,000 pounds-force, which was later upgraded to 7,610,000 pounds-force. Both the second and third stages burned liquid hydrogen, with the third stage being a modified S-IVB capable of restarting the engine for translunar injection.

paragraphs.context: The plugs-out test on January 27, 1967 was filled with issues from the start. The crew detected an odd smell in their suits, causing a delay in sealing the hatch. Additionally, communication problems arose, leading to a pause in the test. As the electrical fire broke out in the cabin, it rapidly spread in the 100% oxygen atmosphere, resulting in high pressure. The cabin eventually burst, causing the fire to spill onto the pad area and hindering rescue efforts. Tragically, the astronauts were unable to be saved and were asphyxiated before the hatch could be opened.

paragraphs.context: Changes were made to address the issues that caused the fire, including using a nitrogen/oxygen mixture instead of pure oxygen during launch, and getting rid of flammable cabin and space suit materials. The quick-release, outward opening door replaced the flammable Block I plug-type hatch cover in the fire-resistant Block II spacecraft. The manned Block I program was discontinued in favor of unmanned Saturn V flights. Crew members would wear modified, fire-resistant Block II space suits regardless of the presence of a LM on the flight.

paragraphs.context: The delay caused by the CSM fire allowed NASA to work on man-rating the LM and Saturn V. The first unmanned Saturn V flight, Apollo 4 (AS-501), took place on November 9, 1967, showcasing the Command Module's heat shield survival during a trans-lunar reentry using the Service Module engine. This was followed by Apollo 6 (AS-502) on April 4, 1968, aiming to achieve trans-lunar injection and a simulated direct-return abort. Despite pogo oscillation and engine issues, the mission controllers successfully completed the flight profile of Apollo 4. With the successful fixes identified from Apollo 6, NASA decided to skip a third unmanned test, declaring the Saturn V ready for manned missions.

paragraphs.context: The lunar rocks brought back from the Moon are incredibly old compared to Earth rocks, dating back around 3.2 billion years for basaltic samples from the lunar maria, and up to 4.6 billion years for samples from the highlands crust. These ancient rocks provide insight into the early stages of the Solar System, a period largely unknown on Earth. One significant discovery from the Apollo Program was the Genesis Rock, collected by astronauts David Scott and James Irwin during Apollo 15. This anorthosite rock is mainly made up of the feldspar mineral anorthite, and is considered representative of the highland crust. The presence of KREEP, a unique geochemical component, in conjunction with the anorthositic samples, suggests that the outer layer of the Moon was once entirely molten.

paragraphs.context: The majority of rocks display signs of the impact process effects, such as micrometeoroid impact craters and high pressure shock waves. paragraphs.context: In 2009, NASA calculated the total cost of the Apollo program in 2005 dollars to be around $170 billion. The Space Review later estimated the total cost of Apollo from 1959 to 1973 to be $20.4 billion, which would be equivalent to $109 billion in 2010 dollars.

This led to the Apollo Applications Program (AAP) which included building a larger orbital workshop from an empty S-IVB Saturn stage. paragraphs.context: The European Union does not have a formal constitution, but its fundamental governance structure is established by the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which have been agreed upon by all 28 member states. These treaties define the powers and responsibilities of the EU institutions, outline the areas in which the EU can create legislation, such as Directives or Regulations. The European Commission proposes legislation, which is then amended and approved by the Council and the European Parliament. The Commission also oversees departments and agencies that enforce EU law. The "European Council", made up of the leaders of member states, appoints Commissioners and the board of the European Central Bank. The European Court of Justice is the highest judicial body that interprets and develops EU law through precedent. It can review the legality of EU institutions' actions and address claims of EU law violations from member states and citizens.

paragraphs.context: The founding treaties of the EU, namely the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), play a crucial role in shaping EU policies and delineating powers between the EU and its member states. European Union law is applicable to member state territories, including certain islands and overseas territories like Gibraltar and the Åland islands, as specified in the TEU. Treaties become effective immediately upon entering into force, unless otherwise specified, and are typically binding indefinitely. The Court of Justice of the European Union has the authority to interpret the Treaties, though validity issues fall under international law. Individuals can invoke primary law in the Court if Treaty provisions are directly applicable and clearly defined.

paragraphs.context: The European Union was initially established with common regulations for coal, steel, and later atomic energy. More substantial institutions were formed through the Treaty of Rome 1957 and the Maastricht Treaty 1992, now known as the TFEU. Amendments were made in the 1960s and 1970s, with major treaties like the Single European Act 1986, Treaty of Amsterdam 1997, Treaty of Nice 2001, and Treaty of Lisbon 2007 enhancing EU development. Several countries joined through accession treaties, including the UK, Ireland, Denmark, Norway (which didn't join), Greece, Spain, Portugal, Austria, Finland, the Czech Republic, and others. Greenland obtained special status through a 1985 treaty.

paragraphs.context: The European Commission, the main executive body of the European Union, operates under Article 17(1) of the Treaty on European Union, which mandates promotion of the Union's general interest. According to Article 17(3), Commissioners should be fully independent and not influenced by any government. The Commission holds the exclusive right to propose Union legislative acts, although the Council plays a significant role in initiating legislative initiatives. Decisions within the Commission, led by President Jean-Claude Juncker, are made through a simple majority vote, typically via a written procedure. Despite Ireland's objection to changes in the Treaty of Lisbon, there remain one Commissioner for each of the 28 member states, including Federica Mogherini as High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy. The appointment of Commissioners undergoes intense negotiations between member states and is subject to approval by the Council and the Parliament. The proposal to have Commissioners drawn from the elected Parliament was not adopted in the Treaty of Lisbon, meaning Commissioners are appointed as unelected subordinates of member state governments.

paragraphs.context: Commissioners have certain privileges, like exemption from member state taxes (excluding EU taxes) and immunity from prosecution for official acts. Abuse of office by Commissioners has been reported, especially following the censure of the Santer Commission by Parliament in 1999, leading to its resignation due to corruption allegations. In a notable case, the European Court of Justice determined that appointing an unqualified dentist as a Commission employee, as seen in the case of Commission v Edith Cresson, did not actually violate any laws. However, a Committee of Independent Experts identified a lack of responsibility among Commissioners, prompting the establishment of the European Anti-fraud Office. An investigation by this office in 2012 into the Maltese Commissioner for Health, John Dalli, alleged that he accepted a €60m bribe linked to a Tobacco Products Directive, resulting in his swift resignation. The European Central Bank, responsible for managing the euro, has some autonomy in monetary policy under the oversight of a six-person board appointed by the European Council based on recommendations. Although the President of the Council and a Commissioner can attend ECB meetings, they are not allowed to vote.

paragraphs.context: The conservative European People's Party is the largest in the Parliament, which cannot initiate legislation against the Commission's wishes. A two-thirds majority may censure the Commission and Council, as happened in 1999. Every five years, Parliament elections are held by proportional representation.

paragraphs.context: The Council, made up of ministers from different member states, convenes every six months, with a President (currently Donald Tusk) providing guidance. Each minister represents their country during meetings based on the topic discussed. Voting in the Council is adjusted based on member state size to prevent larger states from overpowering smaller ones. A qualified majority vote is required for most decisions, meaning at least 55% of Council members representing 65% of the EU population must agree, equivalent to 260 votes out of 352. This is a crucial aspect of the legislative process.

paragraphs.context: TFEU article 294 outlines the ordinary legislative procedure for creating new EU legislation. This process involves three readings, beginning with a Commission proposal. The Parliament can block or suggest changes to the proposal with a majority vote of all MEPs, and the Council can approve changes with a qualified majority or block Commission amendments with unanimity. If there is disagreement between the institutions, a Conciliation Committee is formed to reach a joint agreement. Ultimately, legislation can be blocked by a majority in Parliament, a minority in the Council, and a majority in the Commission, making it challenging to amend EU laws. Enhanced cooperation among a subset of member states requires authorization from the Council, and the Commission must inform member state governments before any legislative proposals are initiated. The EU can only exercise powers outlined in the Treaties, with TEU articles 4 and 5 stating that powers remain with member states unless delegated. The question of ultimate competence to define the EU's competence, known as Kompetenz-Kompetenz, is debated among member state courts, Parliaments, and the Court of Justice.

paragraphs.context: The EU's judicial branch has been instrumental in shaping EU law and advancing economic and political integration through interpreting the treaties. The Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) is the primary judicial body, with the European Court of Justice (ECJ) handling significant cases and the General Court managing less important matters. There is also a Civil Service Tribunal for EU staff matters. Each of the 28 member states appoints one judge with specific qualifications, and a president is elected by the judges for a three-year term. The CJEU is responsible for ensuring that EU law is followed, but it also has the power to develop the law based on its own judgment. Despite most EU law being applied by member state courts, they can seek guidance from the CJEU on EU law interpretation. The CJEU's mission is to uphold the law in treaty interpretation and application, while also shaping and enhancing it through its rulings. Seminal and contentious decisions, such as Van Gend en Loos, Mangold v Helm, and Kadi v Commission, have influenced EU law development.

paragraphs.context: The EU law holds primacy over national laws in cases of conflict, as established by the Court of Justice. In the 1964 Costa v ENEL case, the Italian Constitutional Court ruled that Costa had no claim against the nationalisation law from 1962, as the Treaty of Rome was in force from 1958. The Court of Justice maintained that members states have limited sovereignty and must abide by EU law, as seen in the Amministrazione delle Finanze v Simmenthal SpA case regarding conflicting regulations from 1964 and 1968. While the Court of Justice's rulings emphasize the precedence of EU law, national courts have not always followed suit.

paragraphs.context: Generally, member states believe that while EU law is superior to national law as stated in the Treaties, they do not agree that the Court of Justice has the final say on crucial constitutional matters related to democracy and human rights. In the UK, Parliament is seen as the ultimate expression of democratic legitimacy, with the power to decide on legislation against EU law only if there is a clear desire from the public to leave the EU. It was established in the R (Factortame Ltd) v Secretary of State for Transport case that Parliament voluntarily limited its sovereignty when enacting the European Communities Act 1972, giving UK courts the duty to prioritize EU law over national law. The German Constitutional Court has also emphasized that if the EU violates basic constitutional rights and principles, it cannot override German law. However, as seen in the Solange I and Solange II decisions, as long as the EU is working towards democratizing its institutions and protecting human rights, German constitutional principles will not be used to review EU legislation. This implies that the EU's legitimacy is dependent on the ultimate authority of member states, its actual commitment to human rights, and the democratic will of the people.

paragraphs.context: Constitutional law focuses on the governance structure of the European Union, while administrative law obligates EU institutions and member states to abide by the law. Since 1986, all actions by EU institutions have been open to judicial review, with a particular emphasis on proportionality and respect for general principles of law and fundamental rights. Lawsuits against EU institutions or member states for treaty violations are permitted, as long as the treaties create rights and obligations. Despite this, citizens or corporations were declared unable to sue non-state parties under Directives in 1986. This limited the ability of member state courts to enforce EU law in cases where national rules conflicted. The courts can award monetary damages for legal breaches, but they may also order specific performance or injunctions to uphold the law.

paragraphs.context: In the case of Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen, it was established that the provisions of the Treaties and EU Regulations have direct effect if they are clear, unconditional, and do not require further action for implementation. A postal company, Van Gend en Loos, invoked TFEU article 30 to challenge Dutch Customs Authorities charging tariffs on imported plastics. The Court of Justice ruled that citizens and companies can bring claims under the Treaties, even though they do not expressly grant this right. The Court emphasized that the EU constitutes a new legal order in international law. TFEU article 30 prohibits quantitative trade restrictions without valid reasons, enabling Van Gend en Loos to reclaim the tariff amount. EU Regulations, like Treaty provisions, are directly applicable in all Member States as stated in TFEU article 288. Member states must not duplicate Regulations in their national laws to avoid confusion. In Commission v Italy, the Court held that Italy violated Treaty obligations by not implementing a premium scheme for slaughtering cows and by adding extra rules in a decree. The Court emphasized that Regulations take effect upon publication and any deviation could undermine their uniform application across the Union. Some Regulations may require specific implementing measures, which should be followed accordingly.

paragraphs.context: In the early 1990s, Directives were discussed and debated as to whether they have direct effect on citizens. While treaties and regulations have direct effect, Directives are typically directed at member states, allowing national authorities to choose how to implement them. For example, the Working Time Directive mandates at least 4 weeks paid holidays each year for workers, but many member states require more than 28 days. Despite the argument that Directives should create rights for all citizens, the Court of Justice did not agree, except for five exceptions.

paragraphs.context: If a member state fails to implement a Directive within 10 years, conflicting laws cannot be enforced, and a citizen can use the Directive in legal action (known as "vertical" direct effect). In the case of Pubblico Ministero v Ratti, the Italian government could not enforce a national law against Mr Ratti's business due to its failure to implement Directive 73/173/EEC on packaging and labelling solvents by the deadline. Similarly, a citizen or company can use a Directive in disputes with other private parties, as seen in CIA Security v Signalson and Securitel. Furthermore, a Directive can be invoked in matters of state law principles, as demonstrated in Kücükdeveci v Swedex GmbH & Co KG. Lastly, even non-central government entities can be bound by Directives if they provide a public service with special powers, as shown in Foster v British Gas plc.

If a member state fails to establish an insurance fund for employees to claim unpaid wages in the event of insolvency, individuals can seek damages from the state. An example is the case of Francovich v Italy, where a former employee received 6 million Lira in damages for the failure to set up the required insurance fund. If a Directive grants individuals rights and there is a link between the state's violation and the claimant's loss, damages must be awarded, regardless of the fact that the incompatible law is an Act of Parliament.

paragraphs.context: The principles of European Union law are unwritten rules developed by the European Court of Justice that influence the interpretation and application of EU law. These principles, including fundamental rights, proportionality, legal certainty, equality before the law, and subsidiarity, are derived from various sources such as public international law and legal doctrines from EU member states and the European Court of Human Rights.

paragraphs.context: Proportionality has been considered a fundamental principle of European Union law by the European Court of Justice since the 1950s. As stated in the general principle, the lawfulness of an action is determined by its appropriateness and necessity to achieve legitimate objectives. When faced with various appropriate measures, the least burdensome one should be chosen, ensuring that any adverse effects are not disproportionate to the goals being pursued. This principle is also reflected in Article 5 of the EC Treaty, which specifies that the actions of the Community should not exceed what is required to achieve the objectives of the Treaty.

qas.question: How long has Proportionality been recognized as one of the general principles of EU law?

paragraphs.context: Legal certainty has been established as a key principle in European Union law by the European Court of Justice since the 1960s. This principle, rooted in international law and public law, requires that laws are clear and precise, ensuring that their legal implications are foreseeable, particularly in relation to financial obligations. In order for laws to have legal effect in the EU, they must have a solid legal foundation. Member states must word their legislation implementing EU law in a way that is easily understood by those who are bound by it. The principle of legal certainty in EU law also prohibits retroactive laws, emphasizing the importance of publication before laws take effect. Additionally, the doctrine of legitimate expectation, based on principles of legal certainty and good faith, plays a central role in ensuring individuals are not frustrated in their expectations when acting in accordance with the law.

paragraphs.context: The lack of mention of protection for fundamental rights in the original treaties establishing the European Union led to the focus on preventing member states from violating human rights, resulting in the establishment of the European Convention on Human Rights in 1950 and the European Court of Human Rights. In 1999, the European Council initiated the development of a European Charter of Human Rights to serve as the constitutional basis for the European Union, aligning with the principles outlined in the European Convention on Human Rights and other foundational documents.

paragraphs.context: The European Union law was enhanced in 2007 with the recognition of fundamental rights through the Lisbon Treaty, which acknowledged the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union of 7 December 2000. This Charter now holds the same legal value as the Treaties, making it an essential part of European Union legislation. The European Court of Justice enforces the Charter in relation to EU measures, while the European Court of Human Rights does so for member state actions, allowing both the Charter and the Convention to coexist within European Union law.

paragraphs.context: The Social Chapter, part of the 1997 Treaty of Amsterdam, addresses social policy issues in EU law. In 1989, representatives from UNICE, ETUC, and CEEP laid the groundwork for the Social Chapter. A modified version became the Social Charter at the 1989 Strasbourg European Council, outlining 30 principles like fair pay, workplace safety, and worker rights. This Charter influenced 40 pieces of legislation on vocational training, living conditions, and more in the EU.

paragraphs.context: In 1989, the Social Charter was adopted by 11 out of the then 12 member states, with the UK being the only exception. The UK did not sign the Social Charter and was not held to its legislation unless it agreed to be bound by it. When the Social Charter was proposed to be included in the 1992 Maastricht Treaty as the "Social Chapter", the UK vetoed it and instead, an Agreement on Social Policy was added as a protocol. The UK remained exempt from the protocol unless it agreed to abide by it. Despite not actually being a chapter of the Maastricht Treaty, the protocol became known as the "Social Chapter". The European Union was to "support and complement" the policies of member states in order to achieve the goals of the Agreement on Social Policy.

Subsequently, the UK implemented the key legislation from the Agreement on Social Policy, such as the 1994 Works Council Directive and the 1996 Parental Leave Directive, which mandated workforce consultation in businesses. Over the next decade, the European Union focused on various social policy areas like labour and industrial relations, equal opportunity, health and safety, public health, protection of vulnerable groups, poverty, migrant workers, education, and training following the adoption of the Social Chapter in 1997.

paragraphs.context: The origins of EU Competition law can be traced back to the 1951 European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) agreement signed by France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, and Germany after World War II. Article 65 of the agreement prohibited cartels, while article 66 addressed concentrations, or mergers, and the abuse of dominant positions by companies. This marked the first inclusion of competition law principles in a regional agreement, setting the foundation for the trans-European model of competition law. In 1957, competition rules were incorporated into the Treaty of Rome, forming the European Economic Community (EEC). The treaty aimed to prevent distortions of competition in the common market, with articles 85 and 86 focusing on anti-competitive agreements and the abuse of dominant position by companies. Additionally, articles 90 and 92 outlined principles on competition law for member states, covering public undertakings and state aid. Mergers regulations were not addressed at this time due to lack of consensus among member states.

paragraphs.context: Under the Treaty of Lisbon, Article 101(1) prohibits anti-competitive agreements like price fixing. Any such agreements are automatically void under Article 101(2), with exemptions established in Article 101(3) for collaboration that benefits consumers and innovation. Article 102 addresses the abuse of dominant position, including practices like price discrimination and exclusive dealing. The European Council is allowed to regulate mergers between firms under Article 102 through Regulation 139/2004/EC. Articles 106 and 107 outline competition principles for public enterprises and state aid restrictions to prevent distortion of free competition.

paragraphs.context: The Court of Justice has emphasized the importance of free trade in the European Union since the Treaty of Rome in 1957. The goal is to reduce consumer prices by breaking down barriers to trade and promoting the movement of goods, services, labor, and capital. However, it is important to ensure fair trade practices to protect the interests of workers, consumers, small businesses, developing industries, and communities. The Court of Justice has recognized the need to balance free trade with other values such as public health, consumer protection, labor rights, fair competition, and environmental concerns in order to improve the well-being of individuals.

paragraphs.context: The free movement of goods within the European Union is facilitated by a customs union and the principle of non-discrimination. This means that imports between member states flow freely, with duties prohibited. In Commission v France, the French government was held accountable for failing to prevent French farmer vigilantes from obstructing shipments of Spanish strawberries and Belgian tomatoes. This ruling demonstrated that states can be held responsible for the actions of private actors that hinder trade. Furthermore, in Commission v France French, the Court of Justice established that member states must justify any laws or practices that directly discriminate against imports. This justification must align with specific criteria outlined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Additionally, in Schmidberger v Austria, the Court of Justice ruled that Austria did not violate EU law by allowing a protest to block heavy traffic, highlighting the importance of balancing the free movement of goods with fundamental human rights. When member states invoke Article 36 as a justification for restrictions on trade, they must ensure that the measures taken are proportionate and necessary to achieve a legitimate goal.

The Court found that this labeling was derogatory and that a neutral statement would suffice to protect consumers. Additionally, in a 2009 case, the Court ruled against Italy in a law that prohibited motorcycles or mopeds from pulling trailers. paragraphs.context: Under the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive, efforts have been made to standardize rules on marketing and advertising, prohibiting behavior that manipulates consumer behavior, is deceptive, or aggressive. This Directive aims to prevent unfair competition among traders. In the case of Konsumentombudsmannen v De Agostini, the Court of Justice examined Swedish laws banning advertising to children under 12 and deceptive ads for skincare products. While these bans are deemed justifiable, the Court cautioned against complete marketing bans that could hinder a trader's market access. The Keck and Mithouard case established that restrictions on selling arrangements not altering product content, intended to prevent cut-throat competition, may fall outside the scope of Article 34 of the TFEU. National courts are responsible for assessing the justification of such measures under Article 36 to protect public health. The Directive seeks to prevent a regulatory race to the bottom by harmonizing minimum standards of best practices across the EU, ultimately benefitting consumers.

paragraphs.context: Since its establishment, the Treaties aimed to allow individuals to pursue their life goals in any country through unrestricted movement. Initially, the European Community focused on the movement of workers as an economic factor. However, the focus shifted towards creating a more social Europe from the 1970s onwards. Free movement was increasingly linked to citizenship, granting individuals rights to actively participate economically and socially, rather than economic activity being a prerequisite for rights. This means that the specific worker rights in TFEU article 45 are a manifestation of the general rights of citizens in TFEU articles 18 to 21. According to the Court of Justice, a worker is defined as anyone who is economically active, even if they are not paid monetarily for their work. This was exemplified in the case of Steymann v Staatssecretaris van Justitie, where a German man was allowed to stay in the Netherlands due to his volunteer work in exchange for benefits provided by the community. Being classified as a worker provides protection against discrimination in various aspects such as employment, taxation, and social security. On the other hand, a citizen, defined as someone holding the nationality of a Member State, has rights related to employment and voting but limited access to social security benefits. Despite political debates on the impact of labor mobility, research shows minimal effects on wages and employment for local workers.

paragraphs.context:
The provisions set out in articles 1 to 7 of the Free Movement of Workers Regulation, known as the Hendrix v Employee case, focus on ensuring equal treatment for workers. These articles mandate that workers should have the same opportunities for employment and should not face discrimination compared to nationals of the member state. In the well-known case of the Belgian Football Association v Bosman, Jean-Marc Bosman argued that he should be able to transfer to a different football club when his contract ended, regardless of transfer fees. The Court of Justice agreed that transfer rules could impede free movement and needed to be justified in the public interest.

In instances like the Groener v Minister for Education case, where a requirement to speak Gaelic was justified to promote the Irish language, it had to be proportionate. However, in cases like Angonese v Cassa di Risparmio di Bolzano SpA, a bank could not require a certification only available in a specific location. The Court of Justice also addressed tax benefits, such as in Finanzamt Köln Altstadt v Schumacker, where a man working in Germany but residing in Belgium was entitled to the same benefits as other German residents.

When it comes to social advantages, as seen in cases like the Hendrix v Employee Insurance Institute, equal treatment is mandated. A Dutch national living in Belgium was not entitled to incapacity benefits linked to the Netherlands. Similarly, in Geven v Land Nordrhein-Westfalen, a Dutch woman working in Germany between 3 and 14 hours a week was not eligible for German child benefits. The TFEU article 45 allows limitations on free movement for reasons of public policy, public security, or public health and provides exceptions for employment in the public service.

qas.question: Which articles of the Free Movement of Workers Regulation set out the primary provisions on equal treatment of workers?

paragraphs.context: In 2006, a European ship caused a spill of toxic waste off the coast of Côte d'Ivoire, leading the Commission to consider legislation on toxic waste. Environment Commissioner Stavros Dimas emphasized that it was wrong for such hazardous waste to be transported out of the European Union. In countries like Spain, there was no specific law against shipping toxic waste, prompting Justice, Freedom and Security Commissioner Franco Frattini to suggest establishing criminal penalties for environmental crimes. The Commission's authority to legislate in criminal law was challenged in 2005 but confirmed by the Court of Justice, marking a significant shift in supranational legal power. Opposition in the European Parliament to this new approach was voiced against the intellectual property rights directive, arguing that criminal law should not fall under EU jurisdiction. However, in October 2007, the Court of Justice ruled that while the Commission could propose criminal sanctions, the specifics would need to be determined separately.

paragraphs.context: Evidence suggests that significant changes in Amazon rainforest vegetation have occurred over the past 21,000 years, including during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) and subsequent deglaciation. Debate persists on the extent of this reduction, with some suggesting the rainforest was reduced to isolated refugia while others argue it remained largely intact but with a smaller range. paragraphs.context: The first explorer from Europe to navigate the Amazon River was Francisco de Orellana in 1542. Recent findings from the BBC's Unnatural Histories show that Orellana's reports of a thriving civilization along the Amazon in the 1540s were accurate, and this civilization was later devastated by diseases from Europe, such as smallpox. Geoglyphs dating between AD 0–1250 have been found on deforested land since the 1970s, supporting claims of ancient civilizations. Ondemar Dias discovered the geoglyphs in 1977, with Alceu Ranzi furthering their exploration by flying over Acre. The BBC revealed that the Amazon rainforest has been influenced by human activity for over 11,000 years, involving practices like forest gardening and terra preta.

paragraphs.context: Ctenophora, also known as comb jellies, is a group of marine animals found worldwide. They are characterized by the presence of cilia arranged in ‘combs’ that aid in swimming, making them the largest cilia-swimming animals known. These creatures can vary in size from a few millimeters to 1.5 m (4 ft 11 in) in marine waters. Similar to cnidarians, ctenophores have a jelly-like body with two layers of cells, unlike cnidarians which have only one layer. While some researchers previously grouped them together in the phylum Coelenterata due to their reliance on water flow for digestion and respiration, recent studies have classified them as distinct phyla due to their differences.

paragraphs.context: Most ctenophores are predators, capable of consuming ten times their own weight in a day from microscopic larvae to small crustaceans. Around 100–150 species have been confirmed, with another 25 potentially undescribed. These creatures have retractable tentacles covered in colloblasts for capturing prey. They vary in body shape, with some lacking combs and others using groups of large, stiffened cilia as teeth to catch food. This diversity allows different species to thrive in the same area by specializing in different types of prey.

paragraphs.context: Most species are hermaphrodites, able to produce both eggs and sperm within a single animal, allowing for self-fertilization. Some are simultaneous hermaphrodites, producing eggs and sperm simultaneously, while others are sequential hermaphrodites, with eggs and sperm maturing at different times. Fertilization typically occurs externally, except for platyctenids, whose eggs are fertilized inside their parents' bodies. The young are usually planktonic and resemble miniature cydippids, gradually developing into their adult forms as they grow. Exceptions include beroids, whose young have large mouths and no tentacles, and platyctenids, whose young start as cydippid-like plankton before metamorphosing into adults. In some species, juveniles can reproduce before reaching full maturity, thanks to the combination of hermaphroditism and early reproduction. This unique trait allows populations to grow rapidly even with small numbers.

In bays with high ctenophore numbers, they can regulate small zooplankton populations like copepods, preventing them from depleting phytoplankton crucial for marine food chains. In the Black Sea, the accidental introduction of Mnemiopsis has led to fish stock collapses due to it consuming fish larvae and organisms that would have fed the fish. This issue was worsened by over-fishing and environmental changes that favored Mnemiopsis growth. The unintentional arrival of Beroe helped address the problem by preying on other ctenophores.

paragraphs.context: Despite lacking tentacles, fossils of ctenophores with more comb-rows than modern forms have been discovered in lagerstätten dating back to around 515 million years ago. The evolutionary position of ctenophores has been a topic of debate, with current molecular studies suggesting a closer relationship between cnidarians and bilaterians. Recent analysis suggests that the common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippid-like and that their diverse groups likely emerged after the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 66 million years ago. It has been shown since the 1980s that the "cydippids" are not monophyletic, meaning they do not entirely descend from a single common ancestor, as other ctenophore groups also originate from different cydippids.

paragraphs.context: Ctenophores, like sponges and cnidarians, have two main layers of cells with a middle jelly-like layer known as mesoglea in both cnidarians and ctenophores. More advanced animals have three cell layers and lack this intermediate jelly-like layer. Therefore, ctenophores and cnidarians are commonly classified as diploblastic, similar to sponges. Both ctenophores and cnidarians have a muscle type that, in more complex animals, originates from the middle cell layer. This is why some recent textbooks categorize ctenophores as triploblastic, while others still consider them diploblastic.

paragraphs.context: Ctenophores, also known as Pleurobrachia, Beroe, and Mnemiopsis, exhibit a variety of body plans despite being a phylum with few species. While some oceanic species are delicate and hard to capture intact for study, coastal species must be able to endure waves and swirling sediment particles. Preservation of oceanic species is challenging, with most knowledge coming from photographs and observer accounts. Previous focus has been on the coastal genera Pleurobrachia, Beroe, and Mnemiopsis, with descriptions of ctenophores often based on the cydippid Pleurobrachia in textbooks.

paragraphs.context: The body cavity develops into a system that includes the mouth and pharynx, a stomach-like central area, and internal canals. The inner lining consists of an epithelium called the gastrodermis. The mouth and pharynx have both cilia and strong muscles, while other parts of the canal system feature different cell types based on their proximity to organs. Cells on the closer side store nutrients, produce eggs or sperm, and create bioluminescence, while cells on the further side circulate water through the canals using cilia and rosettes.

paragraphs.context: The cilia on the comb rows, also known as "ctenes" or "comb plates," are suspected to have a supporting function with their 9 + 3 pattern. These cilia can be up to 2 millimeters in length and are oriented in the direction in which the mouth is pointing, providing propulsion for swimming. Some ctenophores are able to swim faster when escaping predators, while others can reverse their direction by changing the power stroke of the comb plate cilia.

paragraphs.context: It is not clear how ctenophores adjust their buoyancy, but some species have been observed relying on osmotic pressure to adapt to water with varying densities. Their body fluids typically have the same concentration as seawater. In lower density environments, ctenophores may use ciliary rosettes to pump water into the mesoglea, increasing its size and reducing its density to prevent sinking. Conversely, when transitioning from brackish to full-strength seawater, the rosettes may pump water out of the mesoglea to decrease its volume and increase its density.

paragraphs.context: The aboral organ, located at the opposite end from the mouth, is the largest sensory feature of a ctenophore. It contains a statocyst, a balance sensor made up of a statolith and balancers that detect orientation. The statocyst is shielded by a transparent dome of long, immobile cilia. Rather than automatically keeping the statolith balanced on all balancers, the ctenophore's response is influenced by its nervous system state, or "mood". For instance, when a ctenophore with trailing tentacles captures prey, it may reverse some comb rows to turn its mouth towards the food.

answers.text: at the opposite end from the mouth

paragraphs.context: Cydippid ctenophores have bodies that are roughly rounded, sometimes nearly spherical or egg-shaped; such as the common "sea gooseberry," Pleurobrachia, which may have an egg-shaped body with the mouth at one end, although some are uniformly round. Two long, slender tentacles extend from opposite sides of the body, each housed in a sheath for protection. Some cydippid species have flattened bodies, wider in the plane of the tentacles.

paragraphs.context: The tentacles of cydippid ctenophores often have tentilla, which are covered in colloblasts that capture prey. Colloblasts are specialized cells in the epidermis with three main parts: a domed head with adhesive, a stalk, and a spiral thread. Some species incorporate prey's nematocytes for defense. Euplokamis' tentilla are unique as they contain striated muscle and have three movements for capturing prey: quick flicking, wriggling, and coiling. These movements are powered by different types of muscle.

paragraphs.context: There are eight rows of combs that are evenly spaced around the body, running from near the mouth to the opposite end. The combs beat in a metachronal rhythm similar to a Mexican wave. A ciliary groove extends from each balancer in the statocyst, under the dome, and then splits to connect with two adjacent rows of combs. In some species, the groove runs along all eight rows of combs, creating a mechanical system to transmit the beat rhythm from the combs to the balancers through water disturbances caused by the cilia.

paragraphs.context: The Lobata possess a pair of lobes that extend beyond the mouth and have inconspicuous tentacles originating from the mouth's corners. These tentacles spread over the inner surfaces of the lobes and do not trail far behind like in the Cydippida. Many lobate species have four auricles between the lobes, which are gelatinous projections edged with cilia to produce water currents that assist in directing microscopic prey toward the mouth. This set of structures allows lobates to feed on suspended planktonic prey continuously.

paragraphs.context: Lobates have eight comb-rows, starting at the aboral pole and typically not extending beyond the body to the lobes. Most lobates move passively through the water by using the cilia on their comb rows for propulsion. Leucothea has active auricles that also help in propulsion. Bathocyroe and Ocyropsis can escape danger by clapping their lobes, causing the expelled water jet to propel them backwards quickly. Unlike cydippids, lobates' comb movements are controlled by nerves rather than water disturbances created by the cilia. Despite this, the comb rows on lobates move in a synchronized Mexican wave style, similar to cydippids and beroids. This coordination may have allowed lobates to grow larger and have less egg-like shapes.

paragraphs.context: The Beroida, also known as Nuda, do not have feeding structures, but their large pharynx inside the spacious mouth is equipped with "macrocilia" for feeding. These large cilia clusters help the Beroida break down prey too large to swallow whole, often other ctenophores. Some Beroe species have adhesive epithelial cells near the mouth that can be connected to "zip" the mouth shut when not feeding. This helps streamline the animal's front while hunting for prey.

paragraphs.context: The Cestida, also known as "belt animals", are planktonic creatures shaped like ribbons, with their mouth and aboral organ situated in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon. They have comb-rows along their aboral edge and tentilla emerging from a groove along the oral edge, which flow back across most of their wing-like body surface. These creatures can move by undulating their bodies and using the beating of their comb-rows. There are two species known, found in warm and warm-temperate waters worldwide: Cestum veneris, also called "Venus' girdle", is one of the largest ctenophores and can reach lengths of up to 1.5 meters (4.9 ft), moving slowly or rapidly. Velamen parallelum, typically less than 20 centimeters (0.66 ft) long, can dart around much faster.

Gonads are situated in the internal canal network under the comb rows, with eggs and sperm being released through pores in the epidermis. While most species undergo external fertilization, platyctenids practice internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch. Self-fertilization has been observed in Mnemiopsis species, indicating that many hermaphroditic species are capable of self-fertilization.

paragraphs.context: Almost all ctenophores are predators, with no herbivores and only one genus that is partially parasitic. If food is abundant, they can consume 10 times their own weight daily. While Beroe mainly preys on other ctenophores, other surface-water species feed on zooplankton varying in size from microscopic creatures like mollusc and fish larvae to small adult crustaceans such as copepods, amphipods, and krill. Haeckelia, a genus within the ctenophores, hunts jellyfish and integrates the stinging cells of their prey into their own tentacles rather than using colloblasts. Ctenophores exhibit diverse feeding techniques, similar to spiders, ranging from hanging motionless in the water to using their tentacles as "webs" to ambushing prey like jumping spiders. The cydippid ctenophore Lampea exclusively preys on salps and attaches to larger salps like a parasite to feed. Pleurobrachia and Bolinopsis, members of the cydippid genus, often have high population densities in the same area because they specialize in different prey types: Pleurobrachia captures strong swimmers like adult copepods with its long tentacles, while Bolinopsis targets smaller, weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae.

paragraphs.context: Previously seen as dead ends in marine food chains due to their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water, ctenophores were considered an inadequate diet for other animals. Despite the challenges of identifying ctenophore remains in possible predators' guts, research on chum salmon revealed they can digest ctenophores much faster than shrimp. Beroids primarily feed on other ctenophores, while jellyfish and turtles consume large quantities of ctenophores, which can sometimes lead to temporary population declines. Generalist fish that prey on ctenophores and jellyfish may have a greater impact on populations than specialist jelly-eaters, as illustrated by herbivorous fishes intentionally consuming gelatinous zooplankton during blooms in the Red Sea. Parasitic larvae of sea anemones and some flatworms also target ctenophores.

paragraphs.context: The Cambrian Stromatoveris fossil, discovered in China's Chengjiang lagerstätte around 515 million years ago, bears a resemblance to Vendobionta from the Ediacaran period. De-Gan Shu, Simon Conway Morris, and their team observed what they believed to be rows of cilia on its branches, indicating a filter feeding mechanism. They proposed that Stromatoveris may have been a distant relative of ctenophores, with ctenophores evolving from sessile ancestors that transitioned into swimming creatures and adapted their cilia from feeding to propulsion.
